repnme.cdata!: Chile - First Public Expenditure Management Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Public Expenditure
            Management Project for Chile were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            balanced project design and adequate team supervision are
            critical to achieve agreed intermediate indicators and final
            goals. The project benefited from a very stable environment
            and it has proven an ideal context for institutional
            reforms. The National Financial Administration System
            (SIGFE) project was instrumental in supporting these reforms
            process, avoiding any disruption and facilitating an orderly
            evolution process of modernization. Chile provides good
            example for many nations. It has decided to take longer, but
            critical steps. By doing so, transparency and governance
            indicators compared with international benchmarks have been
            stable and even facilitated the increase of foreign
            investment and economic growth. The efficient allocation of
            resources and timely reporting have promoted and benefited
            from efficiency gains. It is crucial to incorporate the user
            into the design and implementation process. The Central
            Agencies needed to coordinate both the messages and the
            actions in order to avoid confusion among the other agencies
            and to maximize the impact on government functioning.
            Finally, the importance of institutional tolerance to
            mistakes and the open discussion of alternative solutions
            protected the project goals. In the case of SIGFE, instead
            of insisting on following the original plan, the project
            redesigned the initially complex prototype that was
            interfering with the dissemination process as soon as it was identified.

5086358.trustfund:
TF040703-LATIN AMERICA:FINANCIAL
            MANAGEMENT OF PUBLIC SECTOR MODERNIZATION,TF030667-JAPAN CTF - FY05 GENERAL: LAC
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN LATIN AMERICA AND THE C,TF030486-JAPAN CTF - FY04 GENERAL: LAC
            (ALL COUNTRIES IN LATIN AMERICA AND THE C

abstracts.cdata!:
The Public Expenditure Management
            Project aims at improving the effectiveness, efficiency, and
            transparency of the Chilean public administration, through
            the establishment of a modern, and integrated financial
            management and resource allocation system. Within tight
            fiscal constraints, project components will strengthen
            financial management, and accountability as follows. First,
            a unified information management system will be developed,
            integrating a modular design into a single system for the
            public sector, to validate operational transactions and data
            recording, through extensive, advanced data-communications,
            as institutionally required. Continuous system improvement
            will be established, such as security systems, i.e.,
            procurement, public credit, fixed assets, and inventory
            management. Related sub-systems reform includes updating of
            the accrual based public accounting system, improved cash
            management policies, and procedures, and, procurement
            reforms. Second, a multi-annual financial planning component
            will strengthen capacity to focus on macroeconomic, fiscal,
            and public investment policies, including budgeting by
            results, with technical assistance for public program
            evaluation as key tasks. The third, and fourth components
            will finance the design of a human resources management
            information system, and, strengthen financial, and human
            resource management units respectively, while the fifth
            component will finance the costs of the project coordinating
            unit, i.e., activities, goods and services, operating costs,
            and equipment.
